Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Agency did not complete the required monthly contact between siblings.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/22/2021 it was reported to DCWL that the agency did not complete monthly
contact between siblings as required. The source provided documentation regarding
the foster care case to support the allegation. The documentation was reviewed prior
to contacting the agency to initiate the investigation.
Chief Administrator
On 11/22/2021 the agency’s Chief Administrator was contacted and notified of the
allegation. The CA reported the agency was aware of the possible violation and
provided contact information for the Foster Care Worker(FCW) and the Program
Manager(PM) as she was involved in the case prior to the FCW.
Foster Care Worker & Program Manager
On 12/8/2021 a joint interview was conducted with the FCW and PM. The PM
reported she had a longer history with the case as the FCW was just assigned to it in
August 2021. The PM reported the younger siblings were placed with one another
until August 2021, therefore no sibling visits were required. However, during a recent
court hearing it was identified there were missed visitation opportunities for the two
younger children with their older sibling, Child C. The PM stated Child C was in
multiple placements including hospitalization due to a suicide attempt, detention, and
2

AWOL. As Child C was not always stable, visits were not pursued. The PM
recognized the agency should have thoroughly documented Child C’s inability or
unwillingness to have sibling visits. The PM gave the example of August 2021
specifically, a visit did not occur as Child A was in crisis and Child C had just
returned from AWOL and did not want to see his siblings. While the agency felt there
were sufficient reasons not to have a sibling visit that month, the agency also
acknowledged they should have had more thorough documentation in MiSACWIS.
The PM stated Child C had not been refusing visits, but he generally preferred to “do
his own thing” such as spend time with his girlfriend, rather than attend sibling visits.
The agency was reminded to review FOM 722-06I to ensure they are following the
requirements for documentation when visitation does not occur.
The FCW reported when she was assigned to the case in August 2021, she
recognized some things were missed. Since that time, she has worked to get things
on track and feels a lot of progress has been made. It was noted during the last
court hearing, the judge was happy with the progress in the case.
The FCW and PM were informed that DCWL reviewed the youth’s placement
history. It was found that Child C had multiple placements due to jail/detention,
AWOL, and hospitalization, which made visits difficult. However, during Youth C’s
placement in residential from 3/31/21 to 6/1/21, and placement in Independent Living
from 7/29/21 to 10/23/21 sibling visit attempts should have occurred and been
documented. The PM acknowledged this missed opportunity and stated they have
new plans in place and do not anticipate further difficulties in meeting the
requirements for sibling visits.
Documents reviewed
Reporting source documentation indicated the following:
 During a court hearing on 9/29/21, the judge expressed concern about the
lack of sibling visits completed between Child A, Child B, and Child C. The
court ordered sibling contact to be arranged by the agency and occur at least
once per month.
 The FCW was interviewed and reported a formal visitation schedule had not
been arranged. The FCW reported some barriers to in person visits, such as
transportation barriers and Youth C being in crisis at times, or not wishing to
visit. Stating that phone and video calls were also used to keep the siblings
connected.
 The Program Manager was interviewed and reported phone communication
occurred at times. However, Child C was in crisis for much of the past year,
which affected visits.
 Sibling visits were not entered into MiSACWIS from 12/21/2020 to 9/29/2021.
A MiSACWIS case review determined the following:
 Sibling visits are required to occur monthly, per court order and policy.
 Child A and B were placed together from 5/16/19-8/18/21. On 8/18/21, Youth
A moved to a relative caregiver.
3

 Sibling visits were documented for Youth A and B on 9/24/21 and 10/29/21.
No sibling visits were documented for Youth C.
 Youth C’s placements were as follows: Detention 11/17/20-2/10/21, Licensed
FH 2/10/21-2/15/21, Hospital 2/15-2/19/21, Hospital 2/19/21-3/5/21, Jail 3/5-
3/23/21, Detention 3/23/21-3/31/21, Residential 3/31/21-6/1/21, AWOL
6/1/21-7/29/21, Independent Living 7/29/21-10/23/21, AWOL 10/23/21-
10/24/21, Independent Living 10/24/21- present.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following: (d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are
not placed together except when there is a court
determination that visits are detrimental to either child.
ANALYSIS: A violation was determined due to missing sibling visits and a
lack of documentation regarding attempts to complete visits.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency was reminded to review FOM 722-06I to ensure
they are following the requirements for documentation when
visitation does not occur.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
